skill.name: frontend-css
skill.description: Write and maintain CSS using consistent methodology (Tailwind, BEM, CSS Modules), design tokens, framework patterns, and optimized production builds. Use this skill when writing or modifying CSS files, applying utility classes, styling components, creating design systems, defining color/spacing tokens, or working with CSS frameworks. Apply when working with .css, .scss, .sass files, Tailwind config, styled-components, CSS-in-JS, or any styling code that controls visual presentation, layout, typography, and design consistency across the application.

No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access beyond reading its own documentation files. All 37 static findings are false positives triggered by URL strings in metadata, relative path references in documentation, and hex strings in hash identifiers.

content.user_title: Apply CSS coding standards and methodology
content.value_statement: Writing CSS without consistent methodology leads to maintainability issues and inconsistent styling across projects. This skill provides structured guidance on applying industry-standard approaches like Tailwind, BEM, and CSS Modules to ensure clean, maintainable, and scalable stylesheets.
actual_capabilities: Apply BEM naming conventions for CSS class naming
Configure and use Tailwind CSS utility classes
Implement CSS Modules and CSS-in-JS solutions
Define and manage design tokens for colors, spacing, and typography
Optimize CSS for production with purging unused styles
Resolve styling conflicts and override framework defaults
limitations: Does not execute CSS build processes or compilers
Does not access external CSS libraries or frameworks
Does not generate visual previews of styled components

use_cases.title: Maintain consistent styling
use_cases.description: Apply BEM or utility-first methodology when writing new CSS components for React, Vue, or vanilla projects.

use_cases.title: Define design tokens
use_cases.description: Create consistent color palettes, spacing scales, and typography systems using design token patterns.

use_cases.title: Configure Tailwind CSS
use_cases.description: Set up and customize Tailwind configuration files with custom colors, breakpoints, and utility classes.

prompt_templates.title: Basic CSS styling
prompt_templates.prompt: Write CSS for a button component using BEM methodology with hover and focus states.

prompt_templates.title: Tailwind utilities
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert this flexbox layout to Tailwind CSS utility classes with responsive breakpoints.

prompt_templates.title: Design tokens
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a design token structure for a color system with primary, secondary, and semantic colors.

prompt_templates.title: Production optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this CSS file and refactor it to follow utility-first principles, then suggest how to optimize for production.

output_examples.input: Style a navigation component with dropdown menus using responsive design
output: Tailwind approach: flex, hover effects, responsive breakpoints with md: prefix
Mobile-first media queries for hamburger menu on small screens

output_examples.input: Create a card component with shadow and hover lift effect
output: CSS approach: card class with box-shadow property and transform transition
Design token suggestion: extract shadow values into semantic token set

output_examples.input: Set up a spacing scale for a design system
output: Define spacing tokens: space-1 through space-8 with 4px base unit
Tailwind config: extend theme.spacing with semantic names
Apply consistently using margin/padding utilities or CSS custom properties

best_practices: Use semantic class names that describe purpose, not appearance
Start with mobile-first styles and add responsive breakpoints
Extract repeated values into design tokens for consistency
anti_patterns: Using inline styles instead of utility classes or CSS classes
Overly nested selectors that create specificity wars
Hardcoding magic numbers instead of using design tokens

faq.question: What CSS methodologies are supported?
faq.answer: Supports BEM, utility-first (Tailwind), CSS Modules, and CSS-in-JS patterns for different project needs.

faq.question: Does this skill work with CSS preprocessors?
faq.answer: Yes. SCSS and SASS files are supported with full syntax for variables, mixins, and nesting.

faq.question: Can it help with responsive design?
faq.answer: Provides guidance on mobile-first approaches, breakpoints, and responsive utility classes.

faq.question: Is my project data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a prompt-based skill that only reads files you explicitly open. No data is sent externally.

faq.question: Why does it reference a missing file?
faq.answer: The skill references a local standards document that may not exist in all installations. Core functionality works without it.

faq.question: How is this different from linters?
faq.answer: This skill provides conceptual guidance on methodology while linters enforce syntax rules. Use both together for best results.
